etymology.description: semantic: 舛 + 囗 — footsteps around an enclosure; later phonetic loan for “tanned leather”.
etymology.interpretation: Combines reversed footsteps with an enclosure to depict moving around or surrounding a boundary, a sense linked to 圍 ‘to surround’. The graph was later borrowed for the homophonous word wéi meaning “tanned leather,” so the leather sense is a phonetic loan unrelated to the original picture.
etymology.simplification: PRC simplification reduced 韋 to 韦 by compressing the enclosure-and-footstep strokes into a single streamlined form, enabling it to serve as a common simplified component.

parts.english: contrary; reversed steps; to be at variance

examples.chinese: 韦先生今天来了(韋先生今天來了)。
古人用韦编竹简(古人用韋編竹簡)。
examples.english: In ancient times, people used leather thongs to bind bamboo slips.

examples.chinese: 这件衣服是用韦制成的(這件衣服是用韋製成的)。
examples.pinyin: Zhè jiàn yīfu shì yòng wéi zhìchéng de.
examples.english: This garment is made of tanned leather.
